Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp with a single flared protruding nozzle. The discus is plain except for mouldings around the filling-hole. The shoulder is decorated with four round circles on each side. At the rear is a handle-ornament in the form of a vine-leaf or acanthus palmette (?). The base has a raised ring. Red-brown Nile silt with mica inclusions, covered with a brown slip. Left side damaged; two fragments re-joined.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Late first or early second century AD Egyptian lamp (Bailey 1988, Q1942-3, possibly copying Knidian forms of the period, see Q2702, Q2688).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.09) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5778 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
